DT Article
TI On the distribution of the Indo-malayan Mountain Pit Viper, Ovophis
   convictus (STOLICZKA, 1870), with new records from West-Malaysia and
   Thailand.
FT Zur Verbreitung der Indo-malaiischen Berg-Grubenotter Ovophis convictus
   (STOLICZKA, 1870) mit neuen Nachweisen aus West-Malaysia und Thailand.
AU Gumprecht, Andreas (AGtrimeresurus@aol.com) 
   van Issem, Peter
SO Sauria
VL 35
IS 2
PS 31-44
PD Juni 2013
PY 2013
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Systematics: A valid species according to MALHOTRA et al. (2011), DAVID
   & VOGEL (2012), and in our opinion. Description: Moderately large (max.
   >1 m in total length), females with a stout to massive body, short tail,
   head wide, triangular in dorsal aspect, snout blunt, eyes small, pupil
   vertical oval, adult males much smaller and slimmer than females,
   ventral and subcaudal counts differ between sexes (Table 1), juveniles
   with much lighter and more contrasting colours, earthy shades of brown
   dominant, with pattern of two rows of ([plus or minus] 20) usually
   blackish brown paravertebral spots in alternating or parallel
   arrangement, sometimes fused to form dumbbell-shaped cross bars.
   Distribution and ecology: Insufficiently known from West-Malaysia and
   Thailand (Chumphon Province) (MALHOTRA et al. 2011; DAVID & VOGEL 2012);
   Cambodia (NEANG et al. 2011, Phnom Samkos Wildlife Sanctuary, Veal Veng
   District, Pursat Province, 546 m a.s.l., N 12[degree]07'31.9'', E
   103[degree]07'32.9'', in primary rainforest); distribution pattern a
   mosaic of scattered montane records; few museum vouchers suggest
   secretive nocturnal habits; apparently a predilection for moist slope
   habitats near water, but also found on margins of fields and
   plantations; sheltering under rocks, in rock piles, loose-rock walls,
   leaf litter, piles of wood; occasionally diurnal activity on cool rainy
   days; new records: Ton Pariwat Wildlife Sanctuary Headquarters, a few
   metres from the Ton Pariwat Waterfall, ca. 370 m a.s.l., Phang Nga
   Province, Thailand (KING pers. comm. 2013); road betw. Tanah Rata and
   Brinchang, ca. 300 m down the road to the left to Strawberry Park Resort
   opposite the golf course (1493 m, N 4[degree]29'27.92'' and E
   101[degree]22'49.23''), West-Malaysia (SCHULZ pers. comm.); Kuala Lipis,
   Provinz Pahang, West-Malaysia (SHEAH pers. comm. 2007); Pulau Tioman,
   Prov. Pahang (KOMOROW pers. comm. 2012; a juvenile video-filmed on the
   edge of the new road from Tekkek to Juara, ca. 400 m a.s.l.,
   West-Malaysia. Annotations on some localities: Pulau Pinang: Type
   locality; 2400 ft (about 732 m) alt.; 2nd spec. of O. convictus from
   Penang Hill stored in Raffles Museum of Biodiversity Research, Singapore
   (ZRC.2.2865); Pulau Langkawi: GRISMER (2008; as Ovophis monticola);
   confirmed by junior author (26 May 2009, 10.00 h) from Gunung Rays (881
   m), after heavy rains the night before, at 620 m a.s.l., N 06[degree]
   22.835' and E 099[degree]49.193', temperature ca. 25[degree]C, adult
   female, ca. 65 cm in total length, resting on slope-side (primary
   rainforest) of tar road next to drainage ditch betw. branches and leaf
   litter; no response to approach, but several fierce defensive strikes
   when picked up with stick for transfer to a shrub-strewn meadow across
   the road. Discussion: Known distribution limited to fragmentary records;
   "Sumatra" repeatedly questioned (e.g., DE HAAS 1950), as is "Singapore"
   (e.g., DAVID & VOGEL 2012); "Sumatra" based on BOULENGER (1896, 1912);
   no vouchers in major European collections (ISKANDAR 1986), but one in
   MZB (Bogor, Java) (Oph. 878; June 1941), from N. Sumatra near today's
   Padangsidempuan, at about 1000 m a.s.l.; could be a new species of
   Ovophis. Three additional preserved sumatran specimens found in Museum
   collections: Specimen ZMB 10273 (adult female, coll. BECCARI, don.
   DORIA) from "Singalong" (=Gunung Singgalang volcano, 2877 m, Sumatera
   Barat), West-Sumatra (a 2nd spec. from same loc. in Mus. Civ. Stor. Nat.
   Genova MSNG 30526); erroneously recorded as "Trimeresurus microphtalmus
   PETERS & DORIA, 1878" in SysTax database
   (http://www.biologie.uni-ulm.de/systax/), which is a name never
   published; re-examination confirmed identity as "O. monticola convictus"
   (det. TILLACK 2004). 3rd spec. deposited in Museum Zoologicum Bogoriense
   (MZB Ophi.3555) from Aek Sihura-hura, Sumatera, date of collection: 15
   September 2006. BOULENGER'S (1896) Singapore spec. (BMNH 82.11.27.7)
   tracked down by DAVID et al. (2011) who commented: " ... It should be
   noted that the locality of this syntype is probably erroneous because
   Ovophis convictus is unknown from Singapore. This island is most likely
   the place from which the specimen was purchased or shipped. " Although
   the species appears to have never been found here again, we think its
   occurrence (if not at present anymore than possibly in the past) cannot
   be fully ruled out, as the lowest-altitude record is currently ca. 370 m
   (Thailand, Phang Nga) and the highest peak in Singapore is Bukit Timah
   at 176 m.
C1 Gumprecht, Andreas; Porzer Str 35, Troisdorf, D-53842, Germany, Germany.
EM AGtrimeresurus@aol.com
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0176-9391
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; General morphology; Ecology; Distribution within
   habitat; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   / West / ] [Singapore /  / Record revision] [Thailand /  / ].

DT Article
TI On the identity of Potamanaxas andraemon and its relatives, with the
   description of a new species from Peru (Hesperiidae: Pyrginae:
   Erynnini).
AU Grishin, Nick V. (grishin@chop.swmed.edu) 
SO Tropical Lepidoptera Research
VL 23
IS 1
PS 1-13
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Analysis of male genitalia, wing patterns and wing shapes suggests that
   Potamanaxas perornatus Hayward, 1940, reinstated status is a species
   distinct from P. andraemon (Mabille, 1898); P. andraemon subspecies are
   species-level taxa: P. fuma Evans, 1953, new status and P. forum Evans,
   1953, new status; and the P. fuma type series includes specimens of a
   new species, which is described herein. Potamanaxas lamasi new species
   differs from P. fuma by shape of valvae and maculation. A lectotype for
   Carrhenes andraemon Mabille, 1898 is designated to ensure nomenclatural
   stability. Primary types of these five species are illustrated with
   photographs, and a preliminary identification key to males is given.

   Biophysics and Biochemistry, University of Texas Southwestern Medical
   Center, 5323 Harry Hines Blvd, Dallas, TX, 75390-9050, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Praying mantis of Sabah with special reference to Lower Kinabatangan and
   Danum Valley.
AU Ling, K.L. (estherling123@yahoo.com) 
   Abd Hamid, A.
   Chey, V.K.
   Nazirah, M.
SO Sepilok Bulletin
VL 17-1
PS 77-88
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A total of 827 individuals of praying mantis, comprising 40 species
   belonging to 29 genera and 7 families were recorded from Lower
   Kinabatangan (Sukau, Gomantong) and Danum Valley Conservation Area.
   Danum Valley yielded 35 species from 606 individuals, higher than Lower
   Kinabatangan with 20 species from 221 individuals. There were 15 shared
   species. Mantidae was the most dominant family with 16 species recorded
   accounting for 40% of total species and 52% of total individuals. This
   was followed by Hymenopodidae and Liturgusidae. The most dominant
   species was Hierodula sp. 1 making up to 17% (141 individuals) of the
   total mantis.

   Kinabalu, Sabah, 88400, Malaysia, Malaysia.

   Distribution; faunal list; new record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15003015973
DT Article
TI New Establishment and County Records for Diorhabda spp. (Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae) and Coniatus splendidulus (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) in
   the Texas Panhandle and Western Oklahoma.
AU Michels, G.J., Jr
   Royer, T.A.
   Jones, E.N.
   Lange, R.A.
   Bynum, E.D.
   Ruthven, D.C., III
   Tracy, J.L.
   Bible, J.B.
SO Southwestern Entomologist
VL 38
IS 2
PS 173-182
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 2
U2 15
AB Cooperative projects by various national and state agencies in the last
   10 years have resulted in the establishment of an effective saltcedar
   (Tamarisk sp.) biological control agent, the tamarisk beetle (Diorhabda
   spp.). Three species of tamarisk beetles have been established in
   different regions of Texas, typically based on their climatic
   adaptation. The beetles defoliate saltcedar over multiple seasons,
   weakening and, during 3 to 5 years, eliminating large stands of this
   invasive plant. Another saltcedar biological control agent, the splendid
   tamarisk weevil, Coniatus splendidulus F., is also established in the
   United States from undocumented introductions. Surveys of saltcedar for
   evidence of biological control in the eastern Texas Panhandle and
   western Oklahoma during the summer of 2012 following landowner reports
   of beetle infestations, and previous release efforts along the Canadian
   River in Texas resulted in new state and county records for Diorhabda
   carinata (Faldermann), D. elongata (Brulle), and C. splendidulus F. D.
   carinata x D. elongata hybrids were recorded for the first time in
   Oklahoma, from five western counties. In Texas, hybrids of D. carinata x
   D. elongata, D. carinata, D. elongata, and C. splendidulus were recorded
   from five, 16, one, and three eastern Panhandle counties, respectively.
   A history of the release efforts for establishment of Diorhabda spp.
   from 2004-2010 in the Texas Panhandle is included.
C1 Michels, G.J., Jr; Texas A & M AgriLife Research and Extension Center,
   Amarillo, TX 79106, USA, USA.
RI Royer, Tom/D-9737-2016
OI Royer, Tom/0000-0003-0912-7115
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Parasitology; Genetics
   &Heredity
SN 0147-1724
BD Animals and man; Control; Genetics; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Coniatus splendidulus [Biological control /  / host parasite
   relationships; new record] [Plant hosts / Tamarix / ] [Texas /  /
   distribution]. 
   Diorhabda carinata; Diorhabda elongata [Biological control /  / host
   parasite relationships; new record] [Hybridization /  / ] [Plant hosts /
   Tamarix / ] [Oklahoma /  / distribution] [Texas /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae, Curculionoidea, Curculionidae

TI Revised taxonomic placement of the South American species of Aphonopelma

AB The four species of Aphonopelma currently listed by Platnick (2013) as
   coming from South America are re-examined and discussed. Aphonopebna
   bistriatum (C. L. Koch, 1838) is regarded as a junior synonym of
   Ephebopus murinus Simon, 1892 n. syn.; A. aberrans (Chamberlin, 1917),
   A. pedatum (Strand, 1907) and A. rubropilosum (Ausserer, 1871) are
   regarded as nomina dubia.

DT Article
TI The spiders of the Falkland Islands 1: Erigoninae (Araneae,
   Linyphiidae).
AU Lavery, Alastair H.
   Snazell, Rowley G.
SO Arachnology
VL 16
IS 2
PS 37-60
PD Sum 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Twelve species from subfamily Erigoninae (Linyphiidae) are recorded from
   the Falkland Islands; all are described and illustrated. Five species
   are recorded from the islands for the first time: Notiomaso australis
   Banks, 1914, N. barbatus (Tullgren, 1901), N. flavus (Tambs-Lyche,
   1954), Laminacauda diffusa Millidge, 1985, and L. plagiata (Tullgren,
   1901). In addition, a new genus, Linga gen. nov., and three new species
   are described: Linga orqueta sp. nov., Notiomaso christina sp. nov., and
   N. shackletoni sp. nov. Four species previously recorded are included:
   Notiomaso striatus (Usher, 1983), Laminacauda fuegiana (Tullgren, 1901),
   Neomaso pollicatus (Tullgren, 1901), and the introduced Diplocephalus
   cristatus (Blackwall, 1833).

AN ZOOR15002008410
DT Article
TI THE HIGHLANDS TIGER BEETLE, CICINDELIDIA HIGHLANDENSIS (CHOATE):
   DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, BIOLOGY AND CONSERVATION.
AU Knisley, C. Barry (bknisley@rmc.edu) 
   Hill, James M.
SO Cicindela
VL 45
IS 2-3
PS 17-47
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Most of this study was conducted from 1991 to 1996 because of our
   interest in the apparent rarity of Cicindelidia highlandensis (Choate).
   Follow up surveys in 2004-2005 evaluated any changes in its conservation
   status. Initially known from only two sites in Highlands County, our
   surveys through 1996 included 130 sites and found it at 38 of these in
   one or more years with a grand total count of 945 adults (in 1995), all
   within the Lake Wales Ridge of Polk and Highlands Counties, Florida. The
   2004-2005 surveys produced a grand total of 1603 adults at 39 sites.
   Habitat studies indicated this species was restricted to sandy areas
   with low vegetation cover in a variety of habitats including scrub, pine
   flatwoods, and longleaf pine ridges, often along edges, trails, roads or
   in natural open patches. Cicindelidia scabrosa (Schaupp) was found at 21
   sites, but only at two with C. highlandensis, while Cicindela
   hirtilabris LeConte was found at 60 sites, often with the other two
   species. Field surveys at several sites indicated adults were active
   from mid-May into early August. Monitoring of marked larval burrows
   indicated that development was completed in one year with 10-20%
   survivorship from first instar to adult emergence. Ants were important
   predators on first instar larvae and parasitism from a bee fly Anthrax
   sp., ranged from 14-25% at several sites. A crude estimate of fecundity
   based on counts of ovariole and egg numbers was 25-35 eggs during the
   life of a female. We observed few attacks of adults by asilids none by
   lizards, and we found no elytra of adults in lizard fecal pellets.
   Follow up surveys in 2004-2005 indicated a significant improvement in
   the conservation status of C. highlandensis because several new sites
   were found, additional sites were protected, and management activity to
   create open areas improved habitat quality at some sites. However, most
   sites are small with little habitat, have only small numbers of adults
   and/or are threatened by development or other human activities. The
   species remains a candidate for listing by the U. S. Fish and Wildlife
   Service. Management to reduce vegetation density and create more bare
   ground is needed at most sites and, if implemented, could further
   improve the status for this rare species.
C1 Knisley, C. Barry; 1510 Beaverdam Creek Rd, Crozier, VA, 23039, USA,
   USA.
EM bknisley@rmc.edu
SC Biodiversity &Conservation; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0590-6334
BD Conservation; Ecology; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Cicindelidia highlandensis [Conservation /  / ] [Population dynamics /
   Abundance / ] [Florida /  / biology; distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Cicindelidia highlandensis (Carabidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15002008410
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15002005810
DT Article
TI FINDING UNEXPECTED BEETLES IN ODD PLACES: ARCHICORYNUS KUSCHELI ANDERSON
   AND MARVALDI, A NEW GENUS AND SPECIES REPRESENTING A NEW TRIBE,
   ARCHICORYNINI, OF OXYCORYNINAE (COLEOPTERA: BELIDAE) FROM NICARAGUA.
AU Anderson, Robert S. (randerson@mus-nature.ca) 
   Marvaldi, Adriana E.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 67
IS 2
PS 61-71
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Archicorynus Anderson and Marvaldi, new genus, and its type species,
   Archicorynus kuscheli Anderson and Marvaldi, new species, are described
   from Reserva Natural Cerro Musun, Nicaragua. Adults were collected from
   small dead twigs. A cladistic analysis of 71 adult morphological and
   three biological characters identified Archicorynus as the sister group
   to all remaining extant Oxycoryninae, necessitating recognition of a new
   tribe, Archicorynini Anderson and Marvaldi.
C1 Anderson, Robert S.; Canadian Museum Nat, Div Res, POB 3443,Stn D,
   Ottawa, ON, K1P 6P4, Canada, Canada.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF NOSODENDRON LATREILLE (COLEOPTERA: NOSODENDRIDAE) FROM
   THE CAROLINE ISLANDS.
AU Yoshitomi, Hiroyuki (hymushi@agr.ehime-u.ac.jp) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 67
IS 2
PS 72-74
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of the genus Nosodendron Latreille, 1804 (Nosodendridae),
   Nosodendron carolinense Yoshitomi, new species, is described from Dublon
   Island in the Chuuk Atoll of the Caroline Islands. The species is
   similar to Nosodendron prudeki Hava, 2000 known from southern Thailand,
   but differs by body size, punctation of the mentum, and shape of
   aedeagus. This is the first record of the family from Micronesia.

AB The Malagasy endemic genus Nesiotus Guillebeau is revised. Seven species
   are recognized, including six newly described herein: Nesiotus basalis
   Gimmel, new species, Nesiotus fisheri Gimmel, new species, Nesiotus
   joebranhami Gimmel, new species, Nesiotus nocitus Gimmel, new species,

   provided. A checklist of described Malagasy Phalacridae is also given.

DT Article
TI THREE NEW SPECIES OF PHYLLOPHAGA HARRIS (COLEOPTERA: SCARABAEIDAE:
   MELOLONTHINAE) FROM THE STATE OF PUEBLA, MEXICO.
AU Moron, Miguel-Angel
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 67
IS 2
PS 167-174
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three species of Phyllophaga s. str. Harris from the Mexican state of
   Puebla are described: Phyllophaga aragoni Moron, new species, from
   pine-oak forest on the southwestern slope of Popocatepetl volcano;
   Phyllophaga buapae Moron, new species, from mixed temperate forest near
   Zacatlan; and Phyllophaga cazahuata Moron, new species, from mixed
   forests of Sierra del Tentzo. Drawings of diagnostic structures and
   comments about the similarities of each species with other species in
   the subgenus are provided.
C1 Moron, Miguel-Angel; Inst Ecol AC, Red Biodiversidad & Sistemat, Apdo
   Postal 63, Xalapa, Veracruz, 91000, Mexico, Mexico.
SC Zoology

   America

   Phyllophaga (Phyllophaga) cazahuata [Mexico /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002006394
DT Article
TI Tiny teeth of consequence: Vestigial antemolars provide key to Early
   Miocene soricid taxonomy (Eulipotyphla: Soricidae).
AU Klietmann, Johannes (johannes.klietmann@yahoo.de) 
   Nagel, Doris
   Rummel, Michael
   Ostende, Lars W. van den Hoek
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 12
IS 5
PS 257-267
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB In the soricid fauna of the Early Miocene Petersbuch 28 fissure fill
   from Bavaria, Germany, specimens of Miosorex desnoyersianus (Lartet,
   1851) and Paenelimnoecus micromorphus (Doben-Florin, 1964) retain a tiny
   penultimate antemolar. This antemolar was previously unknown for P.
   micromoiphus, because the tiny antemolar has not been preserved until
   now. Miosorex desnoyersianus retains the rudimentary tooth; its possible
   function was to keep the p4 in upright position. The younger species of
   Paenelimnoecus have lost this vestigial tooth. Based on the alveoli,
   Miosorex pusilliformis is interpreted as a junior synonym of M.
   desnoyersianus, and the diagnoses of Miosorex desnoyersianus and
   Paenelimnoecus micromorphus are emended. 2013 Academie des sciences.
   Published by Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Klietmann, Johannes; Univ Vienna, Dept Palaeontol, Althanstr 14, Vienna,
   A-1090, Austria, Austria.
EM johannes.klietmann@yahoo.de
RI van den Hoek Ostende, Lars W./E-7054-2010
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Paleontology
SN 1631-0683
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Skeletal and supporting
   structures; Skeleton; Dentition; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Soricidae [Teeth / Vestigial antemolars / Taxonomic implications]
   [Germany / Bavaria / ] [Miocene / Early Miocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Insectivores; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Insectivora, Soricidae
OR Soricidae (Insectivora): [Fossil]. 
   Miosorex desnoyersianus - (Lartet 1851) (Soricidae): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 259; Syn nov, Miosorex pusilliformis (Doben-Florin 1964), p. 262;
   Fossil]. 
   Paenelimnoecus micromorphus - (Doben-Florin 1964) (Soricidae): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 261; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15002006394
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15002006395
DT Article
TI A new species of Neochelys (Chelonii, Podocnemididae) from the Ypresian
   (Early Eocene) of the South of France.
AU Perez-Garcia, Adan (paleontologo@gmail.com) 
   de Broin, France de Lapparent
SO Comptes Rendus Palevol
VL 12
IS 5
PS 269-277
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The known European record of the Gondwanan group Podocnemididae begins
   in the Early Eocene. Neochelys underwent a rapid diversification and was
   an abundant and diverse representative of this group during the Eocene
   of Europe from the Early Ypresian to at least the Bartonian. However,
   several of its species are poorly known, and the phylogenetic
   relationships among them are poorly understood. A complete shell from
   the Ypresian of Herault (southern France) is described here. It is
   assigned to a new species, Neochelys liriae. The availability of
   characters of N. liriae is tested by comparison with the other European
   species, which appear to be well differentiated, and particularly with
   the neighbouring French taxa N. eocaenica and N. laurenti, of which the
   latter has been little known to this point. (C) 2013 Academie des
   sciences. Published by Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Perez-Garcia, Adan; Univ Complutense Madrid, Dept Paleontol, C Jose
   Antonio Novais 2,Ciudad Univ, Madrid, E-28040, Spain, Spain.
EM paleontologo@gmail.com
RI Perez Garcia, Adan/I-3114-2015
OI Perez Garcia, Adan/0000-0002-9074-6855
SC Zoology
SN 1631-0683
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Neochelys liriae [France /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Pleurodira, Pelomedusidae
OR Neochelys liriae (Pelomedusidae): [Sp nov, France, Eocene, P. 270;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15002006395

DT Article
TI Deladenus cocophilus n. sp (Nematoda: Hexatylina): A Mycetophagous and
   Entomoparasitic Nematode in Infested Coconut Fruits from Balochistan,
   Pakistan.
AU Nasira, K. (shahinafayyaz@gmail.com) 
   Shahina, F.
   Firoza, K.
SO Journal of Nematology
VL 45
IS 2
PS 106-111
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Deladenus cocophilus n. sp. was isolated from infested coconut fruits in
   Winder, Balochistan, Pakistan. Descriptions are given of the
   entomophagous (insect-parasitic females) and mycetophagous
   (fungus-feeding) free-living females, males, and juveniles. The new
   species D. cocophilus resembles those species in which the excretory
   pore is situated anterior to the hemizonid, namely, D. apopkaetus
   Chitambar, 1991; D. leptosoma Gagarin, 2001; D. ipini Massey, 1974; D.
   laricis (Blinova and Korentchenko, 1986) Ebsarry, 1991; D.
   (siricidicola) canii Bedding, 1974; D. (s) imperialis Bedding, 1974; D.
   nevexii Bedding, 1974; D. (wilsoni) proximus Bedding, 1974; D. (s) rudyi
   Bedding, 1974; D. (s) siricidicola Bedding, 1968; D. (wilsoni) wilsoni
   Bedding, 1968 and D. minimus Chizhov and Sturhan, 1998. The new species
   differs from D. ipini in the absence of a post uterine sac vs. present;
   a = 17 to 30 vs. 35 to 40; stylet = 8 to 10 vs. 11 to 12 [mu]m and
   vulva-anus = 21 to 28 vs. 35 to 48 [mu]m. From D. apopkaetus it differs
   in tail length in female 22 to 28 vs. 31 to 43 [mu]m and in the male it
   is 24 to 32 vs. 30 to 46 mm. It differs from D. leptosoma in the c ratio
   in females, c = 21 to 37 vs. 16 to 22, presence of 6 lines in lateral
   field vs. 10 lines and slightly longer spicules 16 to 18 vs. 15 to 16
   [mu]m. From D. laricis it differs in a shorter stylet length 8 to 10 vs.
   11 to 12 [mu]m; in the c ratio in males 16 to 22 vs. 22 to 35 and
   hemizonid from anterior end 76 to 90 vs. 90 to 119 [mu]m. It also
   differs from the following species: D. (siricidicola) canii; D. (s)
   imperialis; D. nevexii; D. (wilsoni) proximus; D. (s) rudyi; D. (s)
   siricidicola; D. (wilsoni) wilsoni and D. minimus in having shorter tail
   length, lower values of a,b,c ratios and a slightly anteriorly located
   vulva in females.
C1 Nasira, K.; Univ Karachi, Natl Nematol Res Ctr, Karachi, 75270,
   Pakistan, Pakistan.
EM shahinafayyaz@gmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0022-300X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Deladenus cocophilus [Plant hosts / Cocos nucifera / New parasite
   species] [Pakistan /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Deladenus (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P.
   111]. 
   Deladenus cocophilus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Pakistan, Parasite of Cocos
   nucifera (Plant), p. 106; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15002007448
DA 2020-09-17
ER

   Heteroptera: Coreidae).

VL 82

PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species belonging to the family Coreidae, i.e. Cletus tashiae
   sp. n. and Cletus pygophorus sp. n., are described from northern India.
   Species belonging to the genus Cletus STAL are distributed principally
   in the Oriental and Afrotropical regions, with seven species reported
   from India so far.

DT Article
TI Dufourea wuae - a new name and first description of the female
   (Hymenoptera: Halictidae: Rophitinae), with an updated checklist of the
   genus Dufourea in China.
AU Shebl, Mohamed (mohamedshebl2002@hotmail.com) 
   Qiang, Li
SO Polish Journal of Entomology
VL 82
IS 2
PS 83-93
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of the genus Dufourea have the same scientific name,
   Dufourea longicornis (WARNCKE, 1979) distributed in the Middle East, and
   Dufourea longicornis WU, 1982 distributed in China. Dufourea wuae is a
   new name for Dufourea longicornis WU, 1982. The female of Dufourea wuae
   is described for the first time, and an updated checklist of the Chinese
   species of Dufourea is given; there are 29 species in total. Most
   species are distributed in southern China. Twenty-five of the Chinese
   species are endemic; only four are distributed in other areas of the
   western and eastern Palaearctic.
C1 Shebl, Mohamed; Yunnan Agr Univ, Coll Plant Protect, Kunming, Yunnan,
   650201, China, China.
EM mohamedshebl2002@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0032-3780

   Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Dufourea [Checklists / Updated distributional checklist / ] [China /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Apoidea,
   Halictidae
OR Dufourea (Halictidae). 
   Dufourea longicornis - Wu 1982 (Halictidae): [Preoccupied name replaced
   by, Dufourea wuae, p. 85].

   nov, For Dufourea longicornis Wu 1982, p. 85].

DT Article
TI On the occurrence of Turricola sp. in the late Miocene 'calcari a
   Lucina' limestones of the 'Vena del Gesso Romagnol'a Regional Park.
FT Sulla presenza di Turricula sp. nei 'calcari a Lucina' tardo-miocenici
   del Parco Regionale della Vena del Gesso Romagnola (Mollusca Gastropoda
   Conoidea Clavatulidae).
AU Sami, Marco (marco.sami@cheapnet.it) 
   Tabanelli, Cesare
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 37
PS 15-20
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB (On the occurrence of Turricola sp. in the late Miocene "calcari a
   Lucina" limestones of the "Vena del Gesso Romagnola" Regional Park) The
   Miocene-age "calcari a Lucina" (CAL) of Romagna Apennines were.deposited
   in environments comparable to those of the current cold seeps of the
   ocean floor. In analogy with these special environments, the CAL
   limestones housed fossil associations mainly consisting of specialized
   molluscs, above all Lamellibranchs. The authors report the discovery of
   an "unskilled" gastropod referable to the genus Turricula, in Tortonian
   CAL outcropping in the territory of Brisighella (Ravenna).
C1 Sami, Marco; Museo Civ Sci Nat Faenza, Via Medaglie Oro 51, Faenza,
   Ravenna, I-48018, Italy, Italy.
EM marco.sami@cheapnet.it
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1123-6787
BD Systematics; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Turricula [Italy / Romagna / new record; systematics] [Miocene / Late
   Miocene / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Turricula - Schumacher 1817 (Conoidea): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Alvania (Gastropoda: Rissoidae) from North Western
   Turkey.
FT Due nuove specie di Alvania (Gastropoda: Rissoidae) dal nord-ovest della
   Turchia (Gastropoda Caenogastropoda Rissoidae).
AU Tisselli, Morena (luigi.morenagiunchi@alice.it) 
   Giunchi, Luigi
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 37
PS 163-174
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB (Two new species of Alvania (Gastropoda: Rissoidae) from North-Western
   Turkey) The study of samples of sediment taken in Bozcaada Island,
   Turkey, at a depth of 12 m drew authors' attention to two species of
   Alvania that, after study, resulted new to science and are described
   herein. The new species are Alvania bozcaadensis and Alvania campanii.
   The former is compared with Alvania lanciae, Alvania claudioi and
   Alvania discors and the differences between them are given. The latter
   is compared with Alvania datchaensis and Alvania fractospira, two common
   species living in the same area. The new species is compared with
   Alvania josefoi, Alvania scabra and Alvania sculptilis too, since these
   species have similar protoconch.
C1 Tisselli, Morena; Via Novara 19, San Zaccaria, Ravenna, I-48125, Italy,
   Italy.
EM luigi.morenagiunchi@alice.it
SC Zoology
SN 1123-6787

   Atlantic

   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda, Rissoidea
OR Alvania bozcaadensis (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Turkey (marine), P. 164]. 
   Alvania campanii (Rissoidea): [Sp nov, Turkey (marine), P. 165].

DT Article
TI Bangasternus iranensis n. sp from Iran (Insecta Coleoptera
   Curculionidae).
AU Talamelli, Fabio (talamellif@libero.it) 
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 37
PS 233-236
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Description of Bangasternus iranensis n. sp. from Iran, easily
   recognizable from all other species of the genus by its black body
   entirely covered with long erect fluffy bristles, and bifid or trifid
   recumbent hairs.

DT Article
TI Bat Survey in Eastern Terai of Nepal.
AU Thapa, Sanjan (sanjan@smcrf.org) 
   Goit, Rajesh
   Niraula, Ghanashyam
SO Small Mammal Mail
VL 5
IS 1
PS 7-13
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A survey on bats of plains of Eastern Nepal (three districts namely
   Sunsari, Morang and Jhapa) was conducted on October-November, 2008 and
   March-April, 2009 with an objective of recording the species status for
   the first time. Two individuals of single species (Pipistrellus sp.)
   were netted while 13 bats of two species (Scotophilus heathii and
   Pipistrellus sp.) were captured by hands during roost survey, all from
   the houses. Megaderma lyra and Cynopterus sphinx colonies were only
   observed, a dead specimen of Taphozous sp. was collected and measured,
   and two preserved specimens of Scotophilus heathii were measured. Time
   of emergence of their flight was recorded. In total five species of bats
   was recorded during the survey and in conclusion the population of these
   species except Taphozous sp. is rich. There might be chance of recording
   new species to Nepal or even to World from this area.
C1 Thapa, Sanjan; Small Mammals Conservat & Res Fdn, Kathmandu, Nepal,
   Nepal.
EM sanjan@smcrf.org
SC Zoology
SN 2230-7087

   Cynopterus sphinx; Megaderma lyra; Pipistrellus; Scotophilus heathii;
   Taphozous [Nepal / Eastern Terai / Recorded]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates

AB Illustrations, descriptions of the morphology and differential diagnosis
   of three new species of virgulid cercaria (Cercaria agstaphensis 4,
   Cercaria kurensis 1 and C. agstaphensis 12) from the freshwater mollusc
   Melanopsis praemorsa (L.) are presented. Special attention is paid to
   the structure of the glandular apparatus (shape, size, location, secret
   granulation, etc.), excretory system, stylet, and other components of
   the individual structure of cercaria that are of great taxonomical
   importance.

PT J
AN ZOOR15002004907
DT Article
TI Teneriforma pakae sp n. (Calanoida, Spinocalanidae) from the Eastern
   Atlantic.
AU Andronov, V.N. (vandro@mail.ru) 
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 92
IS 6
PS 641-645
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of copepods, Teneriforma pakae sp. n., is described. Adult
   females (0.66, 0.67 and 0.83 mm) and one male (0.64 mm) of the new
   species were found in plankton samples from the coastal waters of
   Morocco and Angola, in total catches at depths of 500-885 m. The new
   species differs from other three known species of the genus Tenertforma
   by the highly elongated body, more compact form of the body, a
   relatively wide and short rostrum, the presence of 5 setae (not 4 setae
   on the endopod of P1, as in T. naso and T. meteorae), and by the
   presence of numerous spines on the posterior surface of P4 coxae. From
   T. pentatrichodes, also bearing 5 setae on the endopod of P1, T. pakae
   differs by a shorter outer spine on distal margin of Re2 P1not reaching
   half the length of the segment bearing it, whereas it is equal to the
   length of the first segment of this very short setae on the sincoxae of
   maxillipeds, and by the location of spermathecae in the female genital
   double somit. The male of T. pakae differs from the male of T. naso by
   the absence of the right P5. Males of other species are not known.
C1 Andronov, V.N.; Russian Acad Sci, PP Shirshov Oceanol Inst, Kaliningrad,
   236022, Russia, Russia.
EM vandro@mail.ru
RI Andronov, Vladimir/L-1947-2016
SC Zoology
SN 0044-5134
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean
DE Teneriforma pakae [North Atlantic / Morocco / New species] [South
   Atlantic / Angola / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Calanoida
OR Teneriforma meteorae - Schulz 1989 (Calanoida): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 644]. 
   Teneriforma naso - Farran 1936 (Calanoida): [Diagnostic characters, P.
   644]. 
   Teneriforma pakae (Calanoida): [Sp nov, Angola (marine), P. 641]. 
   Teneriforma pentatrichodes - Schulz 1989 (Calanoida): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 644].

AN ZOOR15001004729
DT Article
TI A New Andean Species of Leaf-toed Gecko (Phyllodactylidae:
   Phyllodactylus) from Ecuador.
AU Torres-Carvajal, Omar (omartorcar@gmail.com) 
   Carvajal-Campos, Amaranta
   Barnes, Charles W.
   Nicholls, Gabriela
   Pozo-Andrade, Maria J.
SO Journal of Herpetology
VL 47
IS 2
PS 384-390
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We describe a new species of Phyllodactylus from a xerophytic forest in
   the Andes of southern Ecuador. The new species differs from other
   mainland species of Phyllodactylus from South America by the combination
   of the following characters: preanal scales similar in size to other
   ventral scales, well-defined longitudinal rows of tubercles dorsally, a
   medial longitudinal row of enlarged caudal scales ventrally, tubercles
   on dorsal surface of tibia present, enlarged postanal scale absent,
   tubercles on dorsal surface of forearm absent, interorbital scales
   homogeneous in size, enlarged scales on proximal one-fourth of tail
   absent, gular scales granular, and maximum snout-vent length of 55 mm.
   Even though morphological similarity suggests a close relationship
   between the new species and Phyllodactylus reissii, phylogenetic
   analyses of 10 nuclear and mitochondrial genes contradict this
   hypothesis. We also report the first records of Phyllodactylus kofordi
   for Ecuador.
C1 Torres-Carvajal, Omar; Escuela de Biologia, Pontificia Universidad
   Catolica del Ecuador, Avenida 12 de Octubre y Roca, Apartado 17-01-2184,
   Quito, Ecuador, Ecuador.
EM omartorcar@gmail.com
RI Torres-Carvajal, Omar/I-1977-2019
OI Torres-Carvajal, Omar/0000-0003-0041-9250
SC Zoology
SN 0022-1511
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Phyllodactylus kofordi [Ecuador /  / Distribution; new record]. 
   Phyllodactylus leoni [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Phyllodactylus kofordi (Gekkonidae): [New record]. 
   Phyllodactylus leoni (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 385]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15001004729
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14912068824
DT Article
TI A new species of saurolophine hadrosaurid dinosaur from the Late
   Cretaceous of the Pacific coast of North America.
AU Prieto-Marquez, Albert (redshore@gmail.com) 
   Wagner, Jonathan R.
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 255-268
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB We describe and re-evaluate the systematics of specimens from the
   Maastrichtian Moreno Formation of California (western USA) as a new
   species of Saurolophus, the only known genus of hadrosaurid dinosaur
   widespread in Asia and North America. Recognition of this new species
   adds substantially to the record of the taxonomic diversity of these
   animals west of the Rocky Mountains. The new species, Saurolophus
   morrisi, is diagnosed by the possession of a postorbital having
   ornamentation in form of wide oblique groove on jugal process. Placement
   of this new species in Saurolophus considerably expands the distribution
   of this genus, although this referral is arbitrary since phylogenetic
   analysis places the new species outside of the clade formed by
   Saurolophus osborni and Saurolophus angustirostris. However, recognition
   of a new, endemic Californian hadrosaurid, especially one so closely
   related to both Asian and North American species, may have implications
   for future studies of both the internal biogeography of Western North
   America, and the history of exchange with Asia.
C1 Prieto-Marquez, Albert; Bayer Staatssammlung Palaontol & Geol, Richard
   Wagner Str 10, Munich, D-80333, Germany, Germany.
EM redshore@gmail.com
RI Prieto-Marquez, Albert/AAA-1470-2019
OI Prieto-Marquez, Albert/0000-0002-4836-4052
SC Zoology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Saurolophus morrisi [California /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Ornithischia,
   Ornithopoda
OR Saurolophus - Brown 1912 (Ornithopoda): [Emended diagnosis, P. 256;
   Fossil]. 
   Saurolophus morrisi (Ornithopoda): [Sp nov, California, Cretaceous, P.
   257; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912068824
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14912068826
DT Article
TI A new monofenestratan pterosaur from the Kimmeridge Clay Formation
   (Kimmeridgian, Upper Jurassic) of Dorset, England.
AU Martill, David M. (david.martill@port.ac.uk) 
   Etches, Steve
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 285-294
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A specimen of slender skulled monofenestratan pterosaur from the Upper
   Jurassic Kimmeridge Clay Formation of Dorset, UK, is referred to the new
   genus and species Cuspicephalus scarfi. The dentition and posterior
   skull morphology suggest affinities with Darwinopterus, but a close
   relationship cannot be proved. There are also some similarities with the
   pterodactyloid Germanodactylus cristatus, but the presence of teeth on
   the distal rostrum excludes it from that genus. Pterosaur remains are
   rare in the Upper Jurassic of the UK and this specimen represents the
   first significant cranial remains of a pterosaur from the Kimmeridge
   Clay Formation, and possibly the first non-pterodactyloid
   monofenestratan outside China.
C1 Martill, David M.; Univ Portsmouth, Sch Earth & Environm Sci,
   Portsmouth, Hants, PO1 3QL, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM david.martill@port.ac.uk
OI Martill, David/0000-0002-3208-5702
SC Zoology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Cuspicephalus [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Cuspicephalus scarfi [England /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Pterosauria

   species Cuspicephalus scarfi, p. 285, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Cuspicephalus scarfi (Pterosauria): [Sp nov, England, Jurassic, P. 285;
   Fossil].

PT J

DT Article
TI A new albanerpetontid amphibian from the Barremian (Early Cretaceous)
   Wessex Formation of the Isle of Wight, southern England.
AU Sweetman, Steven C. (steven.sweetman@port.ac.uk) 
   Gardner, James D.
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 295-324
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new albanerpetontid, Wesserpeton evansae gen. et sp. nov., from the
   Early Cretaceous (Barremian) Wessex Formation of the Isle of Wight,
   southern England, is described. Wesserpeton is established on the basis
   of a unique combination of primitive and derived characters relating to
   the frontals and jaws which render it distinct from currently recognized
   albanerpetontid genera: Albanerpeton (Late Cretaceous to Pliocene of
   Europe, Early Cretaceous to Paleocene of North America and Late
   Cretaceous of Asia); Celtedens (Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous of
   Europe); and Anoualerpeton (Middle Jurassic of Europe and Early
   Cretaceous of North Africa). Although Wesserpeton exhibits considerable
   intraspecific variation in characters pertaining to the jaws and, to a
   lesser extent, frontals, the new taxon differs from Celtedens in the
   shape of the internasal process and gross morphology of the frontals in
   dorsal or ventral view. It differs from Anoualerpeton in the lack of
   pronounced heterodonty of dentary and maxillary teeth; and in the more
   medial location and direction of opening of the suprapalatal pit. The
   new taxon cannot be referred to Albanerpeton on the basis of the
   morphology of the frontals. Wesserpeton currently represents the
   youngest record of Albanerpetontidae in Britain.
C1 Sweetman, Steven C.; Univ Portsmouth, Sch Earth & Environm Sci, Burnaby
   Bldg,Burnaby Rd, Portsmouth, Hants, PO1 3QL, United Kingdom, United
   Kingdom.
EM steven.sweetman@port.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Wesserpeton [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Wesserpeton evansae [England /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia
OR Wesserpeton (Lissamphibia): [Gen nov, Of family Albanerpetontidae, Type
   species Wesserpeton evansae, p. 298, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Wesserpeton evansae (Lissamphibia): [Sp nov, England, Cretaceous, P.
   299; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912068827
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A Triassic spider from Italy.
AU Dalla Vecchia, Fabio M. (fabio.dallavecchia@icp.cat) 
   Selden, Paul A.
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 325-330
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new fossil spider from the Triassic (Norian) Dolomia di Forth
   Formation of Friuli, Italy, is described as Friularachne rigoi gen. et
   sp. nov. This find brings the number of known Triassic spider species to
   four. The specimen is an adult male, and consideration of various
   features, including enlarged, porrect chelicerae, subequal leg length,
   and presence of a dorsal scutum, point to its identity as a possible
   member of the mygalomorph superfamily Atypoidea. If correct, this would
   extend the geological record of the superfamily some 98-115 Ma from the
   late Early Cretaceous (?Albian, c. 100-112 Ma) to the late middle-early
   late Norian (c. 210-215 Ma).
C1 Dalla Vecchia, Fabio M.; Inst Catala Paleontol M Crusafont, C Escola Ind
   23, Sabadell, E-08201, Spain, Spain.
EM fabio.dallavecchia@icp.cat
RI Selden, Paul/C-7530-2009
OI Selden, Paul/0000-0001-7454-4260; Dalla Vecchia, Fabio
   Marco/0000-0003-3914-3896
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Friularachne rigoi [Italy /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ].

DT Article
TI A termite from the Late Oligocene of northern Ethiopia.
AU Engel, Michael S. (msengel@ku.edu) 
   Pan, Aaron D.
   Jacobs, Bonnie F.
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 331-334
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Termites of the family Stolotermitidae are a relict lineage of primitive
   Isoptera. The fossil record of Stolotermitidae is exceptionally poor,
   with only two Miocene (Neogene) species documented to date. Herein, a
   new genus and species of Paleogene termites is described and figured
   from the Late Oligocene (28-27 Ma, Early Chattian) of northwestern
   Ethiopia (Amhara Region, Chilga Woreda). Chilgatermes diamatensis gen.
   et sp. nov., is most similar to genera of the Stolotermitidae,
   Archotermopsidae, and Termopsidae but can be distinguished on the basis
   of forewing venational details. The genus is tentatively placed in the
   Stolotermitidae: Porotermitinae. Chilgatermes diamatensis is the first
   fossil termite from Ethiopia and, indeed, the first from the entire
   African continent.
C1 Engel, Michael S.; Univ Kansas, Nat Hist Museum, 1501 Crestline Dr Suite
   140, Lawrence, KS, 66045, USA, USA.
EM msengel@ku.edu
RI Engel, Michael S/C-5461-2012
OI Engel, Michael S/0000-0003-3067-077X

   Africa; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Chilgatermes [Oligocene /  / New genus]. 
   Chilgatermes diamatensis [Ethiopia /  / new species] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI Late Cretaceous crest-bearing shrimps from the Sahel Alma Lagerstatte of
   Lebanon.
AU Audo, Denis (denis.audo@edu.mnhn.fr) 
   Charbonnier, Sylvain
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 335-349
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Decapod crustaceans are the most diverse group of fossil invertebrates
   from the Upper Cretaceous Sahel Alma Lagerstatte (Lebanon, Middle East).
   They are mainly represented by abundant crest-bearing shrimps which were
   first described as Penaeus libanensis. We review this species applying
   the new systematic nomenclature and we propose a more complete
   description based on 54 unpublished specimens. This review leads to the
   erection of Palaeobenthesicymus gen. nov. and to the new combination
   Palaeobenthesicymus libanensis that is the oldest record of the family
   Benthesicymidae. A neotype is herein designated. Detailed comparisons
   with extant analogues suggest that the crest bearing shrimps inhabited
   relatively deep water settings most probably exceeding 150 m, at the
   transition between the lower circalittoral and the upper bathyal zones,
   under dysphotic or aphotic conditions.
C1 Audo, Denis; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Hist Terre, CP38,8 Rue Buffon,
   Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM denis.audo@edu.mnhn.fr
RI Charbonnier, Sylvain/AAU-9571-2020
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421

   Description; Combination; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   / Sahel Alma Lagerstatte / ] [Cretaceous / Late Cretaceous / ]. 
   Palaeobenthesicymus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Fossil]. 
   Palaeobenthesicymus libanensis - (Brocchi 1875) (Natantia): [Neotype
   designated, P. 340; Redescription, P. 340; Comb nov, Transferred from
   Penaeus, p. 340; Fossil]. 
   Penaeus libanensis - Brocchi 1875 (Natantia): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Palaeobenthesicymus, p. 339]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912068830

PT J
AN ZOOR14912068834
DT Article
TI A new genus of Norian involutinid foraminifers: Its morphological,
   biostratigraphic, and evolutionary significance.
AU Rigaud, Sylvain (Sylvain.Rigaud@unige.ch) 
   Martini, Rossana
   Rettori, Roberto
SO Acta Palaeontologica Polonica
VL 58
IS 2
PS 391-405
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Late Triassic was a time of pronounced radiation in several groups
   of foraminifers. The rapid evolutionary processes in the Suborder
   Involutinina caused particularly high diversification of these
   aragonitic foraminifers, which became a key group for Upper Triassic
   biostratigraphy. Among them, Triasina hantkeni and Triasina oberhauseri
   are regarded as the most precise guide fossils. However, while these
   species are widely used, a poor documentation of the detailed test
   structure of T. oberhauseri has resulted in misidentifications. The
   exceptional preservation and abundance of Triasina oberhauseri in the
   Upper Triassic deposits of the Black Marble Quarry (Wallowa terrane,
   Oregon, USA) has allowed us to make the first detailed observations of
   its coiling, innermost structure and lamellae arrangement and to
   recognize morphological features that were either wrongly interpreted or
   not described in the original systematic definition of the species. In
   this paper, we demonstrate that the species possesses characteristics
   that hamper its assignment to Triasina and we propose a new genus,
   Aulosina, to accommodate this taxon. Placing emphasis on the accuracy of
   the morphological description, the diagnosis and the systematic
   definition of the species are here improved. The identification of
   innovative features in Aulosina oberhauseri (strengthenings, shortened
   lamellae) highlights new evolutionary trends for the lineage of
   Involutinina that have proved useful for the establishment of
   phylogenetic links between involutinid genera and for understanding the
   evolutive steps leading to the formation of inner-pillars in tubular
   foraminifers. The increasing complexity of Involutinina representatives
   at the end of the Triassic, notably marked by the appearance of internal
   structures in Triasininae, leads us to regard them as probable
   symbiont-bearing foraminifers.
C1 Rigaud, Sylvain; Dept Geol & Paleontol, 13 Rue Maraichers, Geneva,
   CH-1205, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM Sylvain.Rigaud@unige.ch
OI rigaud, sylvain/0000-0003-1713-6927; Rossana,
   Martini/0000-0002-0674-863X
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0567-7920; 1732-2421
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Aulosina [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Aulosina (Foraminiferida): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Triasininae, Type
   species Triasina oberhauseri Koehn-Zaninetti & Bronnimann 1968, p. 393,
   Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Aulosina oberhauseri - (Koehn-Zaninetti & Bronnimann 1968)
   (Foraminiferida): [Comb nov, Transferred from Triasina, p. 393; Fossil].
   
   Triasina oberhauseri - Koehn-Zaninetti & Bronnimann 1968
   (Foraminiferida): [Designated type species for new genus, Aulosina, p.
   393; Fossil]. 
   Triasininae - Loeblich & Tappan 1986 (Foraminiferida): [Redescription,
   P. 393; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912068834
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI On Two New Genera of Pseudoscorpions (Pseudoscorpiones: Chthoniidae)
   from the Northern Mediterranean.
AU Curcic, B.P.M.
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 65
IS 2
PS 151-158
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Pseudoscorpions, assigned to the new genera, Neobalkanella n. gen. and
   Bituberoroncus n. gen., which are distributed in the northeastern and
   northwestern Mediterranean, are described, along with an undetermined
   species of Bituberoroncus. Proofs for the existence of two new genera
   and a previously unknown species are presented. Ecological and available
   zoogeographic information on the taxa is given in brief. The presence of
   a new genus, Neobalkanella n. gen., previously reported from the Balkan
   Peninsula under the name of Tyrannochthonius Chamberlin, is confirmed,
   and the occurrence of another new genus and species, previously unknown
   from the Maritime Alps in France is proved. Illustrations, morphometric
   ratios and linear measurements of all new taxa are provided.
C1 Curcic, B.P.M.; Univ Belgrade, Fac Biol, Belgrade, 11000, Serbia,
   Serbia.
SC Zoology
SN 0324-0770
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe
DE Bituberoroncus nobilissimus [France /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Pseudoscorpionida
OR Bituberoroncus (Pseudoscorpionida): [Gen nov, Of family Neobisiidae,
   Type species Bituberoroncus nobilissimus, p. 153]. 
   Bituberoroncus nobilissimus (Pseudoscorpionida): [Sp nov, France, P.
   154]. 
   Neobalkanella (Pseudoscorpionida): [Gen nov, Of new tribe
   Neobalkanellini, Type species Neobalkanella psoglavi (Curcic 1990), p.
   152]. 
   Neobalkanella psoglavi - (Curcic 1990) (Pseudoscorpionida): [Designated
   type species for new genus, Neobalkanella, p. 152; Comb nov, Transferred
   from Tyrannochthonius, p. 152]. 
   Neobalkanellini (Pseudoscorpionida): [Tribe nov, Of subfamily
   Chthoniinae, Type genus Neobalkanella, p. 152]. 
   Tyrannochthonius psuglavi - Curcic 1990 (Pseudoscorpionida): [Referred
   to, Neobalkanella, p. 152].

TI New Records and Two New Species of the Anaphothrips Genus-Group in Iran
   (Insecta: Thripidae).
AU Mirab-balou, Majid
   Chen, Xue-xin (xxchen@zju.edu.cn) 
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 65
IS 2
PS 159-164
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A key for the identification of eight genera of Anaphothrips genus-group
   (Thysanoptera: Thripidae) from Iran is provided. Two new species of
   Rubiothrips, namely R. tongi sp. nov. and R. parisae sp. nov., are
   described and a key to Iranian Rubiothrips species is provided.
   Thermothrips Pelikan, Rubiothrips vitalbae (Bagnall) and Oxythrips
   claripennis Priesner, are recorded for the first time in Iran.

PT J

DT Article
TI Fungal Pathogens on Some Lepidopteran Forest Pests in Bulgaria.
AU Draganova, S. (sdraganova19@gmail.com) 
   Takov, D.
   Pilarska, D.
   Doychev, D.
   Mirchev, P.
   Georgiev, G.
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 65
IS 2
PS 179-186
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Fungal entomopathogens found in natural populations of 7 lepidopteran
   forest pests were isolated and identified. Beauveria bassiana was
   established as a dominating species followed by Fusarium sp. and
   Aspergillus sp. The pine processionary moth Thaumetopoea pityocampa was
   the most affected by B. bassiana -66.7% of the analysed dead larvae of
   the pest. The occurrence of B. bassiana in Malacosorna neustria, Tortrix
   viridana and Melitaea didyma is the first record in Bulgaria. Relative
   susceptibility of first-second instar Lymantria dispar larvae was
   estimated to three B. bassiana and one Metarhizium anisopliae isolate
   and susceptibility of third instars - to seven B. bassiana and one M
   anisopliae isolate. The bioassays showed that L. dispar larvae were
   tolerant to mycoses caused by the tested B. bassiana isolates and M
   anisopliae. M anisopliae isolate caused mycosis to first-second instar
   larvae with the highest lethal effect 56.67% [plus or minus] 4.84 and B.
   bassiana isolates 561Bb and 575Bb to third instar larvae -47.78% [plus
   or minus] 4.06 and 34.44% [plus or minus] 3.28, respectively, in 17 days
   period.
C1 Draganova, S.; Inst Soil Sci Agrotrcheol & Plant Protect, 7 Shosse
   Bankya Str, Sofia, 1080, Bulgaria, Bulgaria.
EM sdraganova19@gmail.com
RI Doychev, Danail/S-2055-2016; Georgiev, Georgi/AAO-8401-2020
OI Pilarska, Daniela/0000-0002-5582-1397
SC Zoology; Infectious Diseases; Mycology
SN 0324-0770

   diseases; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   / Prevalence; larva] [ / Beauveria bassiana / ] [ / Fusarium / ]
   [Bulgaria /  / ]. 
   Erannis defoliaria [Fungal diseases / Aspergillus niger / Prevalence] [
   / Beauveria bassiana / ] [Bulgaria /  / ]. 
   Lymantria dispar [Fungal diseases / Beauveria bassiana / Susceptibility;
   larva] [Bulgaria /  / ]. 
   Malacosoma neustria; Melitaea didyma; Tortrix viridana [Fungal diseases
   / Beauveria bassiana / New record; larva] [Bulgaria /  / ].

TI A New Cave Species of Genus Alpioniscus (Isopoda: Trichoniscidae) from
   Albania.
AU Andreev, Stoitze (stoitze@abv.bg) 
SO Acta Zoologica Bulgarica
VL 65
IS 2
PS 263-264
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new species Alpioniscus beroni is described based on the material
   from Albania collected in a cave in district Lubrazhd. Regarding some
   characteristics such as pleopod-exopodite I and pereopod-meropodite VII,
   the new species is closer to the species Alpioniscus boldorii, but it is
   clearly distinct by the form of exopodite I and the different structure
   of pleopod II.

DT Article
TI A review of the Genus Hygrocrates with a Description of a New Species
   from Turkey (Araneae: Dysderidae).
AU Kunt, Kadir Bogac (chaetopelma@gmail.com) 
   Marusik, Yuri M.
   Omelko, Mikhail M.

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of fossil Hybosoridae (Coleoptera:
   Scarabaeoidea) from the Early Cretaceous Yixian Formation of Liaoning,
   China.
AU Yan, Zhuo (yanzhuotianli@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Bai, Ming
   Ren, Dong
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 2
PS 139-145
PD Jun 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 17
AB Yan, Z., Bai, M. & Ren, D., 2012. A new genus and species of fossil
   Hybosoridae (Coleoptera: Scarabaeoidea) from the Early Cretaceous Yixian
   Formation of Liaoning, China. Alcheringa, 1-7. ISSN 0311-5518. A new
   genus and species of a well-preserved fossil hybosorine (Coleoptera:
   Scarabaeoidea: Hybosoridae), Fortishybosorus ericeusicus Yan, Bai & Ren,
   is described and illustrated from the Early Cretaceous Yixian Formation
   of Huangbanjigou, Liaoning Province, China. The new fossil can be
   differentiated from all other hybosorines by its large and strong
   mandibles, two spurs of different length on the end of the metatibia,
   three teeth on the outer margin of the protibia, short and robust legs,
   no striae or tubercles on the elytra, and two well-developed wings. This
   is the first record of hybosorids from the Early Cretaceous Yixian
   Formation of Huangbanjigou, Liaoning Province, China.
C1 Yan, Zhuo; Capital Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Beijing, 100048, China,
   China.

DT Article
TI A new species of Scirrotherium Edmund & Theodor, 1997 (Xenarthra,
   Cingulata, Pampatheriidae) from the late Miocene of South America.
AU Gois, Flavio (goisf@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Juan Scillato-Yane, Gustavo
   Armando Carlini, Alfredo
   Guilherme, Edson
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 2
PS 177-188
PD Jun 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Gois, F., Scillato-Yane, G.J., Carlini, A.A. & Guilherme, E. 2013. A new
   species of Scirrotherium Edmund & Theodor, 1997 (Xenarthra, Cingulata,
   Pampatheriidae) from the late Miocene of South America. Alcheringa 37,
   175-186. ISSN 0311-5518. A new species of Scirrotherium Edmund & Theodor
   (Pampatheriidae) is described: S. carinatum. This genus was previously
   represented by a single species, S. hondaensis Edmund & Theodor, 1997,
   recorded from the middle Miocene (Laventan) of Colombia. Pampathere
   remains are common in the Conglomerado osifero' (late Miocene) of the
   Ituzaingo Formation in the Parana River cliffs of Entre Rios, Chubut
   (Argentina) and Acre (Brazil). All of them were referred to
   Kraglievichia paranense, and they are mostly osteoderms. However, only a
   few of these specimens are strictly consistent with that species. The
   new species described herein differs from S. hondaensis in having very
   thin osteoderms with more elaborate ornamentation. The movable band (or
   imbricate) osteoderms have a sculptured exposed surface and a single
   transverse row of anterior foramina; the lateral margins are wider and
   also bear foramina, and the longitudinal central elevation is long and
   proximally wide, and forms a posteriorly raised crest. This elevation is
   delimited by a fairly broad and shallow depression on each side,
   separating the marginal elevation from the longitudinal central one. The
   exposed surfaces of fixed (or fused) osteoderms bear large and deep
   anterior foramina, the longitudinal central elevation and delimiting
   depressions are very pronounced. This new species increases the known
   diversity of the pampatheres from the Conglomerado osifero'.
   Additionally, a new nomenclatural scheme for Pampatheriidae osteoderms
   is proposed.
C1 Gois, Flavio; Museo La Plata, Dept Cient Paleontol Vertebrados, Paseo
   Bosque S-N, La Plata, Buenos Aires, RA-1900, Argentina, Argentina.
EM goisf@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
RI Guilherme, Edson/J-2341-2014
OI Guilherme, Edson/0000-0001-8322-1770

DT Article
TI A spider fossil from the Jurassic Talbragar Fossil Fish Bed of New South
   Wales.
AU Selden, Paul A. (selden@ku.edu) 
   Beattie, Robert G.
SO Alcheringa
VL 37
IS 2
PS 203-208
PD Jun 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Selden, P.A., & Beattie, R.G. 2013. A spider fossil from the Jurassic
   Talbragar Fossil Fish Bed of New South Wales. Alcheringa 37, 201-206.
   ISSN 0311-5518. The oldest fossil spider from Australia is described as
   Talbragaraneus jurassicus gen. et sp. nov., from the Jurassic Talbragar
   Fossil Fish Bed of central New South Wales. Though rather poorly
   preserved, the single juvenile or female specimen has an excavated,
   laterally compressed dorsal side to the fourth metatarsus, reminiscent
   of members of the extant family Uloboridae, to which the fossil is
   tentatively referred.

   from the Zhongzhai section, southwestern Guizhou Province, South China.

AB Zhang, Y., He, W.-H., Shi, G.R. & Zhang, K.-X., 2013. A new
   Changhsingian (Late Permian) Rugosochonetidae (Brachiopoda) fauna from
   the Zhongzhai section, southwestern Guizhou Province, South China.
   Alcheringa 37, 221-245. ISSN 0311-5518. This paper describes 20 species
   (including three undetermined species) of Rugosochonetidae (Brachiopoda)
   in an upper offshore fauna from the Permian-Triassic Boundary Zhongzhai
   section, southwestern Guizhou Province, South China. New taxa are
   Tethyochonetes sheni, Tethyochonetes cheni, Neochonetes (Huangichonetes)
   archboldi, Neochonetes (Sommeriella) waterhousei, Neochonetes
   (Sommeriella) rectangularis and Neochonetes semicircularis.

DT Article
TI REEVALUATION OF TETRAGRAPTUS PHYLLOGRAPTOIDES AND T-AKZHARENSIS BIOZONES
   (LOWER ORDOVICIAN, FLOIAN) FROM THE CORDILLERA ORIENTAL ARGENTINA.
FT Reevaluacion de las biozonas de TETRAGRAPTUS phyllograptoidesy t.
   Akzharensis (ordovicico inferior, floiano) de la CORDILLERA ORIENTAL
   ARGENTINA.
AU Toro, Blanca A. (btorogr@mendoza-conicet.gob.ar) 
   Vento, Barbara A.
SO Ameghiniana
VL 50
IS 3
PS 287-297
PD Junio 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB This paper presents new accuracies and correlations of the Lower
   Ordovician (Floian) biostratigraphic scheme of the Cordillera Oriental.
   The Tetragraptus phyllograptoides and T akzharensis biozones are
   reevaluated based on graptolite records from the lower levels of the
   Acoite Formation, outcropping in the Quebrada de Quinilican (Sierra de
   Aguilar). The stratigraphic range of the characteristic taxa is
   discussed and compared with that observed in Los Colorados area. In the
   Tetragraptus phyllograptoides Biozone, it is worth mentioning the
   presence of Tetragraptus approximates (Nicholson), Tetragraptus sp.,
   Baltograptus geometricus (Tornquist), Cymatograptus demissus (Tornquist)
   and C. rigoletto (Maletz, Rushton and Lindholm) in addition to the index
   species. Tetragraptus amii (Elles y Wood), Cymatograptus protobalticus
   (Monsen), C. balticus (Tullberg) and Paradelograptus sp. appear in the
   lower part of the T akzharensis Biozone, whereas Baltograptus vacillans
   (Tullberg), Corymbograptus v-fractus tullbergi (Monsen), Trichograptus
   dilaceratus (Herrmann), Expansograptus latus (Hall), E. holmi
   (Tornquist), E. constrict-us (Hall), Acrograptus gracilis (Tornquist),
   and A. filiformis (Tullberg) are recorded in the upper portion of the
   same biozone. The regional correlation of both biozones is corroborated
   on the western margin of the Cordillera Oriental. The possible
   subdivision of the T akzharensis Biozone is commented, according to the
   biostratigraphic scheme recently proposed for Scandinavia, and a more
   accurate intercontinental correlation of Northwestern Argentina Floian
   levels is proposed. In addition, the paleoecological implications of
   some studied taxa and the paleobiogeographical relationships between
   Northwestern Argentina and other Gondwanan regions are discussed, and
   the strong affinity with Baltoscandinavia during the Lower Ordovician is
   validated.
C1 Toro, Blanca A.; Univ Nacl Cordoba, Fac Ciencias Exactas Fis & Nat, Av
   Velez Sarsfield 1611,X5016GCA, Cordoba, RA-5000, Argentina, Argentina.
EM btorogr@mendoza-conicet.gob.ar
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0002-7014; 1851-8044
BD Zoogeography; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological
   time periods; Palaeozoic

   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Argentina / Cordillera Oriental /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Ordovician / Lower Ordovician / ].

DT Article
TI NEW SPECIES OF GIANT TORTOISE OF THE GENUS CHELONOIDIS FITZINGER, 1835
   (CRYPTODIRA: TESTUDINIDAE), FROM THE LOWER MEMBER OF THE TOROPI/YUPOI
   FORMATION (LATE PLEISTOCENE/LUJANIAN), BELLA VISTA, CORRIENTES,
   ARGENTINA.
FT Nueva especie de tortuga terrestre gigante del genero CHELONOIDIS
   FITZINGER, 1835 (cryptodira: TESTUDINIDAE), del miembro inferior de la
   formacion TOROPI/YUPOI (pleistoceno tardio/lujanense), BELLA VISTA,
   CORRIENTES, ARGENTINA.
AU Gabriel Zacarias, Gerardo (paleozacarias@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Saul de la Fuente, Marcelo
   Susana Fernandez, Marta
   Eduardo Zurita, Alfredo
SO Ameghiniana
VL 50
IS 3
PS 298-318
PD Junio 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of giant tortoise from the upper section of the lower
   member of Toropi/Yupoi Formation (late Pleistocene, 58-22 ka) is
   described. The holotype of this new species was recovered at Arroyo
   Toropi (10 km south from Bella Vista city, Corrientes Province,
   Argentina). The presence of pectoral scales in the plastron narrower in
   midline and antero-posteriorly expanded towards the marginal scutes,
   allow us to assign this tortoise to the genus Chelonoidis Fitzinger. The
   non parallel lateral margins, the peripheral bones lobed in the bridge,
   the elliptical depression on both sides of peripheral bones III, and a
   sub- rhomboidal entoplastron proximally broadening, with distal
   projections covering the pectoral scales, allow us to recognize a new
   species, Chelonoidis lutzae sp. nov. The strict consensus tree of the
   phylogenetic analysis of Chelonoidis shows a polytomy among Ch. lutzae
   sp. nov., ?Ch. gallardoi (Rovereto), ?Ch. australis (Moreno), and the
   extant and extinct species assigned to carbonaria and chilensis groups.
   The carbonaria group includes Ch. denticulata (Linnaeus) and another
   clade formed by Ch. carbonaria (Spix) and Ch. hesterna (Auffenberg). The
   chilensis group, includes two subclades, one composed by Ch. chilensis
   (Gray), Ch. petersi (Freiberg) and Ch. nigra (Quoy and Gaimard), and
   another formed by YPFB-PAL 0932 and Ch. gringorum (Simpson). Using the
   "pruned tree" option of TNT an "extinct giant continental tortoise"
   clade (Ch. lutzae sp. nov. and ?Ch. australis) is recovered, clearly
   differentiated from the giant Galapagos tortoises.
C1 Gabriel Zacarias, Gerardo; Univ Nacl Nordeste UNNE, Secretaria Gen
   Ciencia & Tecn, Ruta 5,Km 2,5, Corrientes, RA-3400, Argentina,
   Argentina.
EM paleozacarias@yahoo.com.ar
SC Zoology; Paleontology

   South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

TI SYSTEMATICS AND PHYLOGENY OF THE GENUS AMEGHINOMYA IHERING, 1907
   (BIVALVIA: CHIONINAE) FROM THE CENOZOIC OF ARGENTINA AND CHILE.
FT Sistematica y filogenia del genero AMEGHINOMYA IHERING, 1907 (bivalvia:
   CHIONINAE) del cenozoico de ARGENTINA y CHILE.
AU Perez, Damian E. (dperez@macn.gov.ar) 
   del Rio, Claudia J.
   Nielsen, Sven N.
SO Ameghiniana
VL 50
IS 3
PS 354-374
PD Junio 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 1
U2 7
AB A systematic revision of the genus Ameghinomya Ihering, 1907 is
   conducted and its phylogenetic relationships are explored through a
   cladistic analysis based on morphological characters of extant and
   fossil species. The resulting strict consensus shows one clade
   consisting of Protothaca Dall and Austrovenus Finlay and another one
   encompassing the species of Ameghinomya, the latter being monophyletic.
   Ornamentation of the valves is shown to have systematic value which
   until now had not been appropriately explored. Based on the results of
   the phylogenetic and systematic analysis, it is proposed to assign the
   species Venus antiqua King, 1832 (extant, Southwestern Atlantic) and
   Venus chiloensis Philippi, 1887 (Miocene, Chile) to the genus
   Ameghinomya. Ameghinomya camachoi sp. nov. is described from the Carmen
   Silva Formation (Miocene, Isla Grande de Tierra del Fuego, Argentina).
C1 Perez, Damian E.; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat Bernardino Rivadavia, Div
   Paleoinvertebrados, Av Angel Gallardo 470 C1405DJR, Buenos Aires, DF,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM dperez@macn.gov.ar
RI Nielsen, Sven N/A-2187-2009

   [Caenozoic /  / ].

DT Article
TI The family Plectopylidae MOLLENDORFF 1898 in China (Gastropoda:
   Pulmonata).
AU Pall-Gergely, Barna (pallgergely2@gmail.com) 
   Hunyadi, Andras
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 142
IS 1
PS 1-66
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The system of "Eastern Plectopylidae" (China, Vietnam, Taiwan and Japan)
   is revised (excl. Amphicoelina). Three genera are recognised:
   Gudeodiscus n. gen., Sicradiscus n. gen. and Sinicola Gum 1899. From
   Vietnam a new subspecies, Gudeodiscus emigrans quadrilamellatus n. ssp.
   is described. From China, 46 taxa (including 3 doubtful) are recognised
   and the following new species and subspecies are described as new to
   science: G. concavus n. sp., G. emigrans otanii n. ssp., G. eroessi n.
   sp., G. eroessi fuscus n. ssp., G. eroessi hemisculptus n. ssp., G.
   giardi oharai n. ssp., G. giardi szekeresi n. ssp., G. goliath n. sp.,
   G. okuboi n. sp., G. phlyarius werneri n. ssp., G. pulvinaris robustus
   n. ssp., G. soosi n. sp., G. ursula n. sp., G. yanghaoi n. sp., G.
   yunnanensis n. sp., Sicradiscus feheri n. sp., Sic. transitus n. sp.,
   Sinicola asamiana n. sp., Sin. schmackeri n. sp., Sin. stenomphala n.
   sp. The systematic position of two non-Chinese species (from Arunachal
   Pradesh, India) assigned to the genera Sinicola and Endoplon
   respectively, is discussed; Plectopylis (Endopion) aborensis and
   Plectopylis (Sinicola) babbagei both belong to Endothyrella.

PT J
AN ZOOR14912068627
DT Article
TI Radiation of an eastern Mediterranean landsnail genus: revision of the
   taxa belonging to Metafruticicola VON IHERING, 1892 (Gastropoda,
   Pulmonata: Hygromiidae).
AU Bank, Ruud A. (ruud.bank@quicknet.nl) 
   Gittenberger, Edmund
   Neubert, Eike
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 142
IS 1
PS 67-136
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Over the last 30 years, a considerable amount of Metafruticicola
   material has been collected. Here, a monographic revision is provided of
   the genus, which is mainly based on conchological characters, but
   descriptions of the genital system of eight species (and in addition two
   subspecies) are given as well. The distribution area of the genus,
   namely the eastern Mediterranean, ranges from Albania to Israel. In
   total, 24 species are recognized, which are classified into four
   subgenera. Two species are polytypic, accounting for eight subspecies.
   All synonyms and localities are listed, the distribution is illustrated
   on maps, and scanning electron micrographs are given to provide an
   insight of the shell microsculpture (protoconch and teleoconch). New for
   science are: one subgenus (Rothifruticicola), six species (M.
   crassicosta, M. monticola, M ottmari, M pieperi, M. rugosissima, M.
   uluborluensis) and one subspecies (M. nicosiana maasseni).
C1 Bank, Ruud A.; Chopinlaan 21, Hoogezand, NL-9603 AM, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.
EM ruud.bank@quicknet.nl
SC Zoology
SN 0003-9284

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Greece

   Metafruticicola (Rothifruticicola) monticola; Metafruticicola
   (Rothifruticicola) uluborluensis [Turkey /  / New species].

   species for new subgenus, Metafruticicola (Rothifruticicola), p. 82]. 
   Metafruticicola (Cretigena) crassicosta (Helicoidea): [Sp nov, Greece,
   P. 81]. 
   Metafruticicola (Rothifruticicola) (Helicoidea): [Subgen nov, Type
   species Helix redtenbacheri L. Pfeiffer 1856, p. 82].

DT Article
TI Freshwater molluscs from Nepal and North India with the description of
   seven new species (Gastropoda: Bithyniidae, Lymnaeidae, Planorbidae).
AU Gloeer, Peter (gloeer@malaco.de) 
   Boessneck, Ulrich
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 142
IS 1
PS 137-156
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB New records from recent research activities in Nepal and North India
   revealed 20 freshwater gastropod species, of which seven are described
   as new. The most diverse families are the Bithyniidae with six new
   species (Bithynia prestoni n. sp., Bithynia subbaraoi n. sp., Bithynia
   bensoni n. sp., Bithynia reharensis n. sp., Bithynia raptiensis n. sp.,
   Bithynia ghodaghodiensis n. sp.), followed by the Planorbidae with one
   new species, Gyraulus kosiensis n. sp. In addition to the new species,
   we found three that have not been mentioned for Nepal before: Gyraulus
   sivalensis (CLESSIN 1884), G. rotula (BENSON 1850), and Lymnaea
   kashmirensis PRASHAD 1925. The anatomy of most of the species is
   depicted. Additional field work is highly desirable for a more
   appropriate evaluation of the extant freshwater snail biodiversity in
   Nepal.
C1 Gloeer, Peter; Biodivers Res Lab, Schulstr 3, Hetlingen, D-25491,
   Germany, Germany.
EM gloeer@malaco.de

DT Article
TI New data on Cymenorytis COSSMANN from Mediterranean-Atlantic Pliocene
   and Paratethyan Miocene, with the description of two new species
   (Gastropoda Prosobranchia: Vanikoridae).
AU Sosso, Maurizio (sosmauri@gmail.com) 
   Dell'Angelo, Bruno
   Bonfitto, Antonio
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 142
IS 1
PS 157-165
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This study is based on specimens of Cymenorytis COSSMANN 1888 from
   several Italian and Spanish Pliocene localities. Two species, C. landaui
   and C. dellabellai, which were reported before correlated to
   Macromphalus brandenburgi (BOETTGER 1907), are described as new. C.
   brandenburgi is described and illustrated, on the basis of specimens
   from Ukraine and a comparison with a paratype from Costei, Romania, and
   this is the first report of this species for the Middle Miocene
   (Badenian) of Ukraine. C. landaui is known only from the Mediterranean
   Pliocene of Estepona (Spain), while C. dellabellai has a more wide
   distribution, the Mediterranean Pliocene (several N. Italian
   localities), and the European Atlantic Pliocene (Huelva, Spain).
C1 Sosso, Maurizio; Via Bengasi 4-4, Genoa, I-16153, Italy, Italy.
EM sosmauri@gmail.com
RI BONFITTO, ANTONIO AB/K-4219-2015
OI BONFITTO, ANTONIO AB/0000-0001-9399-4208

SN 0003-9284

   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Cymenorytis dellabellai [Italy /  / new species] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
   Cymenorytis landaui [Spain /  / new species] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   163; Fossil]. 
   Cymenorytis dellabellai (Gastropoda): [Sp nov, Italy, Pliocene, P. 161;
   Fossil].

   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912068630
DT Article
TI Fossil Clausiliidae from Ceresole d'Alba (Piedmont; Middle Pliocene),
   with remarks on Triptychia (Filholiidae) and the Helicoidea from the
   same site (Gastropoda: Stylommatophora).
AU Nordsieck, Hartmijt (hnords@t-online.de) 
SO Archiv fuer Molluskenkunde
VL 142
IS 1
PS 167-180
PD June 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In this paper the Clausiliidae of the Middle Pliocene site Ceresole
   d'Alba (Cuneo province, Piedmont, Italy) are described. The clausiliid
   fauna comprises eight species, five of them available as complete shells
   and (or) apertural fragments, three only as apical fragments and thus
   not determinable as species. The following genus and species taxa are
   described as new: Neostyriaca (Lombardiella) n. subgen., Parafusulus
   (Pliofusulus) n. subgen., Clausilia (C.) ceresolensis n. sp.,
   Neostyriaca (Lombardiella n. subgen.) prostrobeli n. sp., Parafusulus
   (Pliofusulus n. subgen.) latestriatus n. sp. The systematic problems
   round the clausiliid species are discussed. Zoogeographical and
   ecological remarks on the clausiliid fauna are added. Besides,
   annotations on the Triptychia species (Filholiidae) and the helicoid
   fauna of Ceresole d'Alba are given.
C1 Nordsieck, Hartmijt; Forschungsinst Senckenberg, Senckenberg Anlage 25,
   Frankfurt, D-60325, Germany, Germany.
EM hnords@t-online.de

   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Amphidromus Albers, 1850 from Sumba,
   Indonesia (Gastropoda Pulmonata Camaenidae).
AU Cilia, David P. (dpcilia@gmail.com) 
SO Biodiversity Journal
VL 4
IS 2
PS 263-268
PD Jun 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The camaenid Amphidromus (Syndromus) junior n. sp. from an isolated
   forest in the east of Sumba island in the Indonesian archipelago is
   described. Its closest named relative is Amphidromus (Syndromus) abbasi
   Chan et Tan, 2010, and some conchological features are common for both
   species. However, the new species is smaller, with consistent
   differences in shell thickness, pattern and pigmentation.
C1 Cilia, David P.; 29 Triq il Palazz 1 Ahmar, Santa Venera, Malta, Malta.

   264].

TI A remarkable new flightless Madrasostes Paulian, 1975 from Vietnam
   (Coleoptera Scarabaeoidea Hybosoridae Ceratocanthinae).
